citation.abstract: Ionotropic γ-aminobutyric acid (GABA)-gated chloride channels belong to the cys-loop superfamily of ligand-gated ion channels (cys-loop LGICs) and mediate fast inhibitory synaptic transmission in the nervous system and at neuromuscular junctions of insects. Insect GABA-gated cation channels have also been described. The sequencing of insect genomes has enhanced our understanding of the subunits that make up GABA receptor gene families of many species, including a genetic model organism (Drosophila melanogaster) as well as pest, vector and beneficial (pollinator) species. Individual GABA-gated chloride channel subunits can be subject to alternative splicing and RNA editing. These post-transcriptional modifications can add to the diversity of GABA-gated chloride channel subtypes. Insecticides acting on GABA-gated chloride channels include polychlorocycloalkanes, cyclodienes, macrocyclic lactones, phenylpyrazoles, isoxazolines and metadiamides. Structural studies are not yet available for invertebrate GABA receptors but are available for an invertebrate L-glutamate-gated chloride channel and a vertebrate (human) ionotropic GABA-gated chloride channel β3 subunit, thereby facilitating the modelling of insect GABA-gated chloride channels. Repeated applications of cyclodienes in the post-war years resulted in high levels of resistance, the molecular investigation of which led to the identification of the Rdl (resistance-to-dieldrin) locus, encoding a GABA-gated chloride channel subunit. A single channel-lining mutation was associated with dieldrin resistance. Understanding the molecular basis of resistance has accelerated the development of field diagnostic tests. Toxicity issues relating to insecticides targeting GABA-gated chloride channels are addressed, including the impact on beneficial insect species (pollinators), mammals and wildlife.
citation.title: Mechanisms of action, resistance and toxicity of insecticides targeting GABA receptors.
